column3: The different social classes are involved in this government because some have more impact than others.  The text states" The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods. column3: The Third Wave was initially nothing more than an experiment which Jones created to represent how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening. As the experiment went on, the students which participated became so loyal to the experiment and it gradually became out of hand. This was not Jones' intention, he merely just wanted to use the experiment as a learning experience for his students. The experiment ended simply because it was slipping out of Jone's control and he felt that it was becoming too powerful.
column4: The Third Wave was initially conceived as a means for Jones to explore how individuals throughout history would follow the crowd, even during challenging times. As the experiment progressed, the participants' unwavering devotion to the experiment led to an uncontrollable expansion. Jones' initial intention of using the experiment for educational purposes slowly transformed into a sense of compulsion and powerlessness as the experiment spiraled out of his control.

column3: The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government was shaped like a pyramid, they had the lowest classes and the highest classes. At the top of the pyramid is the Pharaoh, which was like the Egyptian king. Pharaohs were worshipped and admired as they held the most power in the social classes. They were believed to be gods and had many responsibilities, protection is most important. A Pharaoh's assistant is a vizier, viziers made sure taxes were collected and they worked with scribes to keep the government records, they could also read and write. Right below the Pharoah were nobles and priests. Nobles held government posts and profited from tributes. Priests pleased the gods. Right before the lowest portion of the pyramid are the craftsman, physicians, and merchants. Craftsmen made and sold important supplies like jewelry, pottery, papyrus, products, tools, etc.  These items needed to be seld from the artisans and traders, so merchants sold these goods to the public. At the bottom of the pyramid were the slaves and farmers. Their job was to farm and to work for whoever needed their help.
column4: The Ancient Egyptian system of government functioned like a pyramid. The lowest class was occupied by the pharaoh, the ruler of the land. They were revered and worshipped as gods, wielding significant power. Following the pharaoh on the pyramid was a vast array of government officials. Nobles held positions in the government, profiting from tributes and influence. Priestess played a critical role in pleasing the gods, located right below the pharaoh. Craftsmen, physicians and merchants played essential roles in supporting the government, facilitating trade and production. At the base of the pyramid were the slaves and farmers. Their duty was to work and maintain the stability of the land.

column3: The meatpacking that was conducted in the industry in Chicago was disgusting. The author, Upton Sinclair, explained how there were various ways in which the workers in the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. Some of how workers would use or cover up spoiled meat were the action of rubbing the meat with soda to take away the smell, filling up ham with pickle, the workers also had a stronger pickle that destroyed odor, the invention of a new device by a person to extract the bone, from which the bad part generally lay, and insert in a white-hot-iron. These various ways in which the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat are all discussed in the second paragraph of the excerpt from The Jungle.
column4: The meatpacking industry in Chicago was a gross issue. Upton Sinclair, the author, exposed how workers in the factory engaged in various deceitful practices to cover up spoiled meat. These tactics included rubbing spoiled meat with soda, filling hams with pickle, and using a stronger pickle that eliminated odor. A device was also invented by an individual to extract the bones from spoiled meat, with the bad parts being discarded into a white-hot iron.

column3: The various ways the factory could use or cover up spolied meat include mixing it with frsh meat, dousing it in chemicals, or just mixing anything and everything together to make sausages. " This quotes shares how the factories can simply make any meat look good no matter how old or molded it is. A third way that the factories can use spolied meat is by making it into sausages, "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."(3) The repulsive truth behind the making of sausagaes is explained in this quote, also adding to the explination of the factories simply coering their products in chemicals to sell again.

They used various tactics to disguise the spoiled meat, sometimes by adding it to other meats or by making it appear fresh through chemical manipulation. Additionally, they could transform spoiled meat into sausages and sell it, highlighting the lengths to which they went to conceal the truth.

column3: The text says that the social structure works similar to that of a pyramid.  At the top, of course, is the gods. Because, I mean, THEY'RE GODS. Underneath them is the Pharohs. This is due to the fact that people believe that the Pharohs were the human versions of the gods. The Pharohs held the most responsiblility and were the most powerful. They were also buried within stone pyramids. Beneath the Pharohs lies the Nobles, who essentially were the government. To quote from the text, they "profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh." Oh yeah, and the Preists (also up here with the Nobles) had the job of making sure that the gods were happy, and didn't hypothetically cause the destruction of humanity,  but THAT DOESN'T MATTER. Anyways, next is the middle class. the middle class, of course, was in the middle.  It contained craftsmen(men refering to both men and women, plus the possible addition of nonbinary peeps if the term hypothetically existed at the time) and shopkeepers. But what did they make? What did they sell? Well what do YOU think?? Ok, I might understand if you were having trouble figuring out what craftsmen did(which was make things such as jewlery,pottery, and tools by the way),  but shopkeepers??? I think you might be able to find out yourself. OK, MOVING ON, we have soldiers. Who, in most societies, you might expect to be higher than the middle class, but NOPE. THEY'RE AT THE BOTTOM. Well, not at the bottom, but.. Let's just say that in the egyptian society, you're either at the top, or at the bottom. And, despite the existence of the middle class, THERE IS NO INBETWEEN. So, yeah. Soldiers. They uh, fought in wars, of course, and they also supervised the peaseants and farmers...That's all I really know. Sorry. Alright, and now the moment in which you bois n gals n nonbinary pals have all been waiting for...the absolute bottom...the lowest of the lows...drumroll please...SLAVES AND FARMERS, YALL! Aight so slaves were essentially made out of a whole bunch of peeps who were taken captive during war, and such. They were used to work on building projects, and let's be honest, were probably treated like crap. And farmers, on the other hand, were...FARMERS! And they did, uh...Very..Farmer-y things. They..THEY WERE FARMERS. They also helped build royal monuments, and, to quote from the text, "paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest". So, if their yearly harvest were hypothetically around, let's say...$10,000, then they'd be left with...*calculating*...$4,000. So, when it came to taxes, farmers, too, WERE TREATED. LIKE. CRAP. (and I personally dont think that the farmers should be so low because unlike everyone else, they make the food that's KEEPING EVERYONE ELSE A L I V E. that's just how I see it thought.)
column4: Sure, here is a rewritten version of the passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "The social structure in ancient Egypt functioned similarly to a pyramid. At the apex, we find the gods, who held immense power and responsibilities. Below them were the nobles, who exercised some level of influence. The middle class was positioned in the middle, comprising craftsmen and shopkeepers who played a vital role in society. In contrast, soldiers occupied the lowest position, responsible for warfare, maintenance, and maintaining order. Despite a clear hierarchy, the existence of a middle class is not explicitly mentioned in the text.  The slaves and farmers, on the other hand, were the lowest rung in the social hierarchy. They were captured during war and forced to work on building projects, producing agricultural goods, and contributing to the construction of royal monuments. Their contributions were essential to maintaining the civilization, but their rights and welfare were often neglected.  The text highlights the immense disparity between the classes, with the gods enjoying exceptional privileges and the lower classes being subjected to harsh conditions. This social structure was rigid and stratified, with no room for in-between possibilities.

column3: Fear and pity are the first elements of a perfect tragedy. column3: There are multiple aspects that must be written or shown to portray an ideal tragedy. Foremost, a tragedy should not solely appeal to human satisfication where the villain would blatantly receive a revenge of sorts. Instead, it should provoke a certain amount of pity and fear through "unmerited misfortune (and) the misfortune of a man like ourselves (commonlit.org)." Furthermore, the person to whom the tragedy is occurring to should neither be good or bad, and his life should fall apart through a mistake. Additionally, an ideal, well-constrcuted plot should include a singular, focused issue in which there is no complexity with two simultaneous problems. Thus, factors such as emotional provokation, characteristics, and the way in which the tragedy is written all influence the development of an ideal tragedy.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy that are described by Aristotle are plot, character, and diction. Plot should give a single issue and not double and should be from good to bad in terms of change of fortune. The fortune should come as a result of error in a character from better to worse and imitate pity and fear. Character should be defiant of a bad man passing from adversity to prosperity from the spirit of Tragedy and possess no tragic qualities and related to the audience to create emotions. Diction or choice of words should be arranged in a simple, but complex plan and imitate actions of pity and fear, while also thoroughly satisifing moral sense and well-being. Evidence to support these statements are in paragraphs 2 and 3 where it reads, " A plot of this kind would, doubtless, satisfy the moral sense, but it would inspire neither pity nor fear; for pity is aroused by unmerited misfortune, fear by the misfortune of a man like ourselves...A well-constructed plot should, therefore, be single in its issue, rather than double as some maintain. The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad. It should come about as the result not of vice, but of some great error or frailty, in a character either such as we have described, or better rather than worse... the character between these two extremes — that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgement or frailty...A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan. It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation. It follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity." These pieces of evidence further support my assertion of the three main elements of an ideal tragedy being plot, character, and diction by showing the importance of a plot and its significance of portraying pity and fear and character and its importance of showing one's personality to be from adversity to prosperity, while showing the significance of diction and its well-being of providing a sense of pity and fear and satisying moral sense throughout the play and tragedy in its choice of words.
column4: Sure. Here is a rewritten version of the passage, with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  An ideal tragedy must feature a single, developing plot that unfolds from good to bad in terms of change in fortunes. The character of a tragic hero should be defiant of a bad man, starting with adversity and rising to prosperity through a reverse transformation in fortunes. The tragedy should express emotions including pity and fear effectively, utilizing contrasting methods to elicit emotional responses from the audience. Lastly, the quality of diction and the selection of words must match the tone and theme of the play, injecting the play with a sense of pity and fear while also satisfying the moral sense, and the overall well-being and satisfaction of the audience. The evidence supporting these attributes, as mentioned in the passage, further strengthens the assertion that plot, character, and diction are the cornerstones of an ideal tragedy.

column3: The factory would often mask the smell of the spoiled meat by "giving them thirty percent", which used a pump that was stronger than usual to destroy the smell. They would also rub soda on the meat at times to take away the spoiled smell, Sinclar says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters." Another way they would cover up spoiled meat would be taking the bone out and replacing it with a white-iron rod, as Sinclair states, "after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad... they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron", and then they would label these as "boneless hams", getting rid of the three level grading scale. In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would also just mix it in with non spoiled meat, to make it look like they had used one-hundred percent non spoiled meat. The factory would also take in old sausage that had been rejected and use chemicals to mask the spoilage, and then reuse it, Sinclair goes more in depth when he says, "there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."

They also used a white-iron rod to replace the bone after the hams had been smoked, injecting a small amount of chemicals to mask the smell. Another way they covered up spoiled meat was to mix it in with non-spoiled meat to make it look like they had used all non-spoiled meat. The factory also took in old sausage that had been rejected and used chemicals to mask the spoilage, then reused it for home consumption.

column3: In On Tragedy , written by Aristotle, the elements present in an ideal tragedy are listed. According to Aristotle, a tragedy should, "morover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear," (Paragraph 2). He then goes on to show explain how an author can initiate these feelings in the audiance through specific characters and their mistfourtunes. Aristotle also goes on to say that the protagonist in a tragedy should not be someone who is perfect and saint-like, but it also should not be someone who is evil. He says, "There remains, then, the character between these two extremes-that of a man who is not emminently good and just, yet whose mistfourtune is brough about not by vice," (Paragraph 2).  The final element that, accodring to Aristotle, makes an ideal tragegy is the change of fourtune. He says, "the change of fourtune should not be from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad," (Paragraph 3). If the main character were to have a happy ending, then the drama would closer resemble a comedy rather than a tragedy. In summary, according to Aristotle, nuetral characters, a bad change in fourtune, and the ability to excite pity and fear are all elements of an ideal tragedy.
column4: Sure, here is the reworked passage:     In Aristotle's play "On Tragedy," he outlined the elements that make an ideal tragedy. According to Aristotle, a tragedy should evoke strong emotions, particularly feelings of pity and fear. An author can achieve this by depicting characters who experience misfortune and whose lives are characterized by moral complexity. The protagonist should be neither a flawless hero nor an evil villain, but a character who embodies the human condition. Finally, the play should feature a significant shift in fate, from good to bad, as this is what typically elicits a response of pity and fear in an audience.

column3: Throughout this novel, Aristotle lists the ideas of what makes a tragedy a tragedy. One of those first ideals was the complexity of the tragedy. Another element that Aristotle thought was key to a tragedy was that the man should fall because of an error he makes in his judgment. He believed a man's downfall should not come from his opposition but from his own lack of judgment. The last element Artisole list is that it should be a well-consturcted plot that deals with a single issue.
column4: Aristotle's analysis of tragedy centers on several essential characteristics that contribute to its tragedy: complexity, error of judgment, and a well-structured plot. Each element plays a specific role in immersing the reader in the tragic world.
